key_title: Key to the species of Epilobium

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Onagraceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Onagraceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1996). Onagraceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plants more or less erect; lowlands to alps
Plants creeping or prostrate; alpine or subalpine
Seeds with a pale cellular rim surrounding ventral face; mainly damp situations at high altitudes
Seeds without a pale cellular rim
Stems and leaves lacking long, spreading non-glandular hairs; leaves mostly opposite, at least on lower parts of stems
Plants with a dense covering of conspicuous long, spreading non-glandular hairs; leaves mostly alternate or opposite

Dead leaves often retained on base of stems; inner surface of hypanthium glabrous or with very sparse tufts between stamen bases; fruiting pedicel 1.5–5 cm long; mainly dry, rocky slopes at high altitudes
Dead leaves not normally retained on base of stems; inner surface of hypanthium with a line of hairs between stamen bases; fruiting pedicel usually less than 3 cm long
Petals to 5.5 mm long; papillae on seeds arranged in obvious longitudinal lines
Petals 3–14 mm long; papillae on seeds not arranged in obvious longitudinal lines
Inflorescences erect; flowers usually less than 2 cm across
Inflorescences nodding; flowers large and showy, 2 cm or more across
Erect perennial to c. 1.2 m high with an indumentum of fine spreading hairs c. 0.5 mm long; leaves mostly alternate, linear to narrow-lanceolate, often grey-green; petals to 8 mm long

Robust perennial to c. 2.5 m high with an indumentum of large, spreading, often straight hairs c. 1–2 mm long; leaves mostly opposite, lanceolate-elliptic to narrow-elliptic, green; petals more than 8 mm long
Seeds with a pale cellular rim
Seeds without a pale cellular rim
Tips of stems often somewhat ascending; coma absent from seeds
Plant completely prostrate; coma present on seeds
Plant completely prostrate; leaves opposite throughout, margins entire or with few weakly developed teeth
Tips of stems often somewhat ascending; leaves opposite on lower stems, alternate near inflorescences, margins with sparse, shallow teeth
